Abstract: Muscle contraction is a complex process driven by the intricate interplay of structural proteins and regulatory mechanisms. This study delves into the structural biochemistry of muscle contraction, focusing on the roles of actin, myosin, the ryanodine receptor, and troponin. Utilizing advanced cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) and cryo-electron tomography (cryo-ET) techniques, we elucidate the conformational changes and interactions that underpin muscle contraction at the molecular level. Our findings reveal detailed insights into the actin-myosin cross-bridge cycle and the regulatory function of troponin in response to calcium ion fluctuations mediated by the ryanodine receptor. These structural insights enhance our understanding of the molecular basis of muscle function and have implications for addressing muscle-related diseases. This research underscores the power of cryo-EM and cryo-ET in resolving dynamic protein structures, providing a comprehensive view of the molecular machinery driving muscle contraction.
